text: I think one of the things that's maybe a little bit undervalued is this kind of agency piece. And I think about this a lot, which is, you have a lot of people that could go through college and go through school and they're basically told exactly what to do on a P-set. They're given these very, very, I would say, well-defined paths that they need to take. I think maybe in society and just school, we don't prioritize how do you make sure you get people with real agency that want to build something, right?
speaker: Varun Mohan
context: Lenny asks Varun what skills people should be investing in more with the rise of AI building more and more of our products. Varun explains that beyond technical skills like understanding computer systems and problem-solving, the most undervalued skill is agency - the ability to take initiative and build things independently rather than just following well-defined instructions. He contrasts this with traditional education where students are told exactly what to do, arguing that society doesn't prioritize developing people who have real agency and want to create something meaningful.
text_ko: 조금 과소평가되는 것 중 하나가 이런 자기 주도성(agency) 측면인 것 같아요. 이걸 많이 생각하는데, 대학이나 학교를 다니면서 P-set(문제 풀이 과제)에서 뭘 해야 할지 정확히 지시받는 사람이 많아요. 그들에게는 따라야 할 아주 딱 정해진 길만 주어지죠. 사회나 학교에서는 뭔가를 만들고 싶어하는 진짜 자기 주도성(agency)을 가진 사람들을 어떻게 키울지 우선순위로 두지 않는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得有一个东西可能被低估了，就是这种主动性。我经常想这个问题，就是很多人上大学的时候，做作业都是老师告诉你怎么做，给你安排得明明白白的路径。我觉得可能在社会上，包括在学校里，我们都没有重视怎么培养那些真正有主动性、想要去创造点什么的人，对吧？
text_es: Creo que algo que tal vez no valoramos lo suficiente es este tema de la autonomía personal. Y pienso mucho en esto: tienes un montón de gente que puede pasar por la universidad, por toda su educación, y básicamente les dicen exactamente qué tienen que hacer en cada tarea. Les dan estos caminos súper, súper definidos, diría yo, que tienen que seguir. Creo que tal vez en la sociedad y en la educación no priorizamos cómo asegurarnos de formar gente con verdadera autonomía que realmente quiera construir algo, ¿no?
key_sentence: Agency piece is undervalued; we need people who want to build something.

text: I want the company to almost be like this dehydrated entity. Every hire is like a little bit of water, and we only go back and hire someone when we're back to being dehydrated.
speaker: Varun Mohan
context: Lenny asks Varun how he knows when it's time to hire someone at Codeium. Varun explains his hiring philosophy using a metaphor - he wants the company to operate lean like a dehydrated entity, where each new hire is like adding water. They only hire when teams are truly underwater and desperately need help, not when they have adequate resources. This prevents the politics and manufactured work that happens when companies hire before they actually need people.
text_ko: 회사를 거의 탈수된 존재(dehydrated entity)처럼 유지하고 싶어요. 채용은 사람 한 명 한 명이 물 한 방울 같은 거라서, 다시 탈수 상태가 됐을 때만 사람을 뽑아요.
text_zh: 我希望公司就像一个脱水的生物体一样。每招一个人就像加了一点水，只有当我们又"脱水"了，才会再去招人。
text_es: Quiero que la empresa sea casi como una entidad deshidratada. Cada contratación es como un poquito de agua, y solo volvemos a contratar a alguien cuando ya estamos deshidratados otra vez.
key_sentence: Company is a dehydrated entity; hire only when needed.

text: A lot of the bets we're making inside the company are for things that are not three, four weeks away. We should be cannibalizing the existing state of our product every six to 12 months. Every six to 12 months, it should make our existing product look silly. It should almost make the form factor of existing product look dumb.
speaker: Varun Mohan
context: Varun discusses what he considers the most counterintuitive aspect of building AI products. While users and the market focus on short-term weekly improvements, internally Codeium is making longer-term bets that aren't visible for months. He explains their philosophy of continuously disrupting their own product - every 6-12 months they should be building something that makes their current offering look outdated and obsolete in both functionality and design.
text_ko: 우리가 회사 안에서 하는 많은 베팅(bets)은 3~4주 안에 끝나는 일이 아니에요. 6~12개월마다 기존 제품을 카니발라이징(cannibalizing)할 수 있어야 해요. 매번 6~12개월마다 새로 나온 게 기존 제품을 우스꽝스럽게 만들고, 기존 제품의 폼팩터(form factor)가 어리숙해 보일 정도여야 해요.
text_zh: 我们公司内部下的很多赌注都不是三四个礼拜就能见效的。我们应该每隔六到十二个月就颠覆一下现有产品。每隔六到十二个月，就要让我们现在的产品看起来很傻，甚至让现有产品的外形设计看起来都很蠢。
text_es: Muchas de las apuestas que estamos haciendo dentro de la empresa son para cosas que no van a pasar en tres o cuatro semanas. Deberíamos estar canibalizando el estado actual de nuestro producto cada seis o doce meses. Cada seis o doce meses, debería hacer que nuestro producto actual se vea ridículo. Casi debería hacer que el factor de forma (form factor) del producto existente se vea súper tonto.
key_sentence: Cannibalizing our product should make it look dumb every six to 12 months.

text: The engineers are now able to produce more technology. The ROI of building technology has actually gone up. This actually means you hire more. The best thing to do is just get your hands dirty with all of these products. You could be a force multiplier to your organization in ways in which they never even anticipated.
speaker: Varun Mohan
context: Lenny asks about skills people should invest in with AI building more products. Varun argues against the common belief that AI will reduce demand for engineers. Instead, he explains that AI tools make engineers more productive, increasing the return on investment of building technology. This higher ROI actually justifies hiring more engineers, not fewer. He encourages people to get hands-on experience with AI tools because they can become force multipliers in their organizations in unexpected ways.
text_ko: 엔지니어들이 이제 더 많은 기술을 만들어낼 수 있어요. 기술을 만드는 것에 대한 투자수익률(ROI)이 실제로 올라갔고, 이건 결국 더 많이 채용해야 한다는 뜻이에요. 가장 좋은 방법은 이런 제품들을 직접 뛰어들어 써보고 손으로 다뤄보는 거예요. 그렇게 하면 당신은 조직에서 그들이 전혀 예상하지 못한 방식으로 영향력을 배가시키는 존재(force multiplier)가 될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 现在工程师们能开发出更多技术了。搞技术的投资回报率(ROI)其实是在上升的。这其实意味着你得多招人。最好的办法就是亲自上手去试试这些产品。你可能会成为组织里的力量倍增器(force multiplier)，发挥出他们想都想不到的作用。
text_es: Los ingenieros ahora pueden desarrollar más tecnología. El ROI de crear tecnología en realidad ha subido. Esto significa que vas a contratar más gente. Lo mejor que puedes hacer es meterte de lleno con todos estos productos. Podrías ser un multiplicador de fuerza (force multiplier) para tu organización de maneras que ni siquiera se imaginaban.
key_sentence: ROI of building technology has increased; get your hands dirty with products.

text: I think one of the worst things is like, if someone comes here and doesn't like using these tools, we believe there are massive productivity improvements. We do bring people into the company on site so we can actually see how they think through problems on a whiteboard and all these other pieces. So we do want to see how they think on their feet and hopefully they're not just taking what we're saying, putting it in a voice translator and sticking it into ChatGPT and getting the answer out.
speaker: Varun Mohan
context: Lenny asks how Codeium conducts interviews in an era where AI tools like Windsurf can solve coding problems. Varun explains their approach to modern technical interviews - they actually encourage candidates to use AI tools during interviews because they believe in the productivity improvements these tools provide. However, they also conduct on-site interviews with whiteboarding to assess real-time problem-solving abilities and ensure candidates aren't just mechanically translating problems into AI prompts without genuine understanding.
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 제일 안 좋은 상황 중 하나는, 누군가가 여기 와서 이런 도구 쓰는 걸 싫어하는 거예요. 우리는 이런 도구들이 생산성을 엄청 끌어올린다고 보고 있어요. 그래서 사람들을 실제로 사무실(온사이트 on-site)로 불러 화이트보드 앞에서 문제를 어떻게 풀어가는지 같은 과정을 직접 보려고 해요. 즉석에서 어떻게 생각하는지 보길 원하고, 단지 우리가 말한 걸 음성 번역기(voice translator)에 넣어서 ChatGPT에 붙여 넣고 답만 뽑아내는 식이 아니길 바래요.
text_zh: 我觉得最糟糕的情况就是，如果有人来了之后不愿意用这些工具，我们是真心相信这些工具能大幅提升工作效率的。我们会把人请到公司现场，这样就能实实在在地看到他们怎么在白板上思考问题，还有其他各种表现。所以我们确实想看看他们的临场反应能力，希望他们不只是把我们说的话丢进语音翻译器，然后再扔给ChatGPT来找答案。
text_es: Creo que una de las peores cosas es cuando alguien llega aquí y no le gusta usar estas herramientas, porque nosotros creemos que hay mejoras enormes de productividad. Por eso traemos a la gente a la empresa en persona para poder ver realmente cómo razonan los problemas en la pizarra y todo eso. Queremos ver cómo piensan sobre la marcha y ojalá que no estén simplemente tomando lo que decimos, metiéndolo en un traductor de voz y pegándolo en ChatGPT para sacar la respuesta.
key_sentence: We want candidates who can think on their feet, not just use voice translators.

text: I think maybe in society and just school, we don't prioritize how do you make sure you get people with real agency that want to build something, right? Their goal is not just to maybe graduate from college and then get a job at a big tech company where they're told exactly what to do or where to put the pixel for this one website. I think that's maybe a skill set that is undervalued just right now, probably in the last maybe 10 years or so.
speaker: Varun Mohan
context: Varun continues explaining why agency is an undervalued skill in the AI era. He critiques how society and educational systems don't prioritize developing people with genuine agency who want to create meaningful things. Instead, many people follow a predictable path of graduating college and joining large tech companies where they're given very specific, narrow tasks like positioning pixels on websites. He argues this lack of agency has been undervalued for about a decade and will become increasingly important.
text_ko: 저는 사회나 학교에서 진짜로 뭔가를 만들고 싶어 하는 사람들의 주체성(agency)을 어떻게 확보할지 우선순위로 두지 않는 것 같아요. 그들의 목표가 단지 대학을 졸업해서 빅테크(big tech) 회사에 들어가 거기서 시키는 대로만 하는 것—예를 들어 어떤 웹사이트의 픽셀(pixel)을 어디에 놓으라고 지시받는 일—이 아니잖아요. 이런 스킬셋(skill set)이 요즘, 아마 지난 10년 정도 동안 특히 저평가돼 온 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得可能在社会上，包括学校里，我们都没有重视一个问题：怎么培养那些真正有主动性、想要创造点什么的人才，对吧？他们的目标不应该只是从大学毕业，然后去大厂找个工作，每天被人安排得死死的，就负责在某个网页上调调像素位置什么的。我觉得这种能力可能被低估了，特别是最近这十年左右。
text_es: Creo que tal vez en la sociedad y en las escuelas no le damos prioridad a cómo asegurarnos de formar gente con verdadera iniciativa que quiera construir algo, ¿no? Su objetivo no es solo graduarse de la universidad y luego conseguir trabajo en una empresa tecnológica grande donde les digan exactamente qué hacer o dónde poner cada pixel en una página web. Pienso que esa habilidad está subvalorada justo ahora, probablemente en los últimos diez años más o menos.
key_sentence: Real agency is undervalued; graduates shouldn't just follow orders in tech jobs.
